title: NHS vows to cut single-use plastic by up to half
text:
The NHS has launched a major drive to cut single-use plastic in hospitals (Picture: Getty)

The NHS has pledged to slash single-use plastics in hospitals across England in an effort to reduce waste and help the environment.

Last year the NHS bought 163 million plastic cups, 16 million plastic cutlery pieces, 15 million straws and two million stirrers.

Health chiefs said the drive aimed to halve this figure to a total of around 98 million throwaway items.

On-site retailers Boots, M&S and WH Smith have signed up to the pledge and aim to get rid of straws and stirrers from April 2020, phasing out cutlery, plates and cups over the following year.

NHS England chief executive Simon Stevens said: ‘It’s right that the NHS and our suppliers should join the national campaign to turn the tide on plastic waste.

‘Doing so will be good for our environment, for patients and for taxpayers who fund our NHS.’

The move will affect staff and patient canteens as well as on-ward catering and hospital retailers.

The NHS bought almost 200 million disposable plastic items last year (Picture: PA)

The NHS has written to hospitals urging them to back the campaign.

Sheffield Teaching Hospitals NHS Foundation Trust has already cut more than half a million single-use plastic items from its canteens.

Meanwhile, the Yorkshire Ambulance Service has reduced plastic waste from staff canteens by around four tonnes a year.

Ruth May, chief nursing officer for England, said: ‘Support from local NHS organisations to sign the pledge and cut use of catering plastics will need all NHS staff to take action in their own areas and encourage their employers to go further faster.’

Helen Bird, of sustainability charity Wrap (the Waste and Resources Action Programme), added: ‘It’s positive to see the NHS taking action to turn the tide on plastic waste, removing plastic items where they do not make sense for the environment, and looking for alternatives to materials which are not recyclable, like expanded polystyrene cups.

‘It sends a strong message to the public and suppliers to the NHS; our throwaway culture will become a thing of the past.’
